Nice building to take a picture? but hell to get there. Very noisy area , difficult to travel even on foot

column8: Do visit but don't expect too much beyond ground level
column11: We went to the Jami Ul-Afar mosque as it was unique in its colour scheme and looked more like something from Charlie and the Chocolate factory than a mosque. You have a wait a bit to go in.  Some guy "shows" you around but in actual fact he does absolutely nothing and just takes you to the balconies on the upper floor.  It was a complete waste of time and a waste of money as he will force you to tip him for literally doing nothing. Stay on the ground floor and get your photos and leave.  It's a working mosque so people are praying and there are people all around you trying to honour their religion so not sure how much they appreciate the tourists coming to visit. Worth a very brief trip but don't expect to be marvelled.
Very unusual due to its red color. Located quite near the market. Access to inside is OK but the beauty is in the exterior appearance.
This mosque is in the Pettah market area and stands out due to its red colour. Was able to go inside and look around. Worth a visit.

column8: Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque ‚Äì The Iconic Red Mosque of Colombo üá±üá∞
column11: Located in the heart of Pettah, the Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque is one of Colombo‚Äôs most recognisable landmarks and a true architectural masterpiece. Built in 1908, this historic mosque stands out with its vibrant red and white candy-striped fa√ßade, a style that makes it instantly eye-catching and unique. The building‚Äôs intricate design and towering minarets are truly fascinating, and the peaceful interior offers a quiet contrast to the bustling Pettah streets outside. Visitors are welcome to explore parts of the mosque respectfully, it‚Äôs spacious and beautifully maintained. It‚Äôs best to walk or take a taxi, as parking nearby can be difficult due to the narrow streets. You will also find many other local attractions and markets just steps away, making it a great stop during a city walk. A must viait spot for anyone exploring Colombo‚Äôs heritage and vibrant culture. ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
In the heart of Colombo on the busy street is the great temple. A must visit and picture take for when visiting Sri Lanka. Would recommend

Welcoming, warm, friendly, chatty,  informative, witty,  public relations ambassador named Shan at building entrance. Sri Lankans are lovely, hospitable, peaceful people with infectious smiles. Look for Shan; he will make you smile. Thank you, Shan for job well done ‚ù§Ô∏è BTW unique, impressive mosque architecture

column8: Historic mosque in Colombo, Sri Lanka with unique architecture
column11: It is a historic mosque in Colombo, Sri Lanka, located on Second Cross Street in Pettah. The mosque is one of the oldest mosques in Colombo and a popular tourist site in the city. Built in 1908, it's architecture is unique with alternate red and white bands like candy.  Very interesting place to visit, but parking in the streets is a bad. Best to walk here or taxi. Inside it's covered and large area to see. Many tourists can be seen here.

column8: Beautiful mosque, to visit for tourists
column11: Gigantic mosque, which blends completely into the busy district and at the same time stands out enormously. The mosque looks beautiful from the outside and is huge inside. It can be visited by tourists (m/f/x). The entrance is through gate 3. Everyone gets appropriate clothing if you don't wear it at that time. This is followed by a short and enthusiastic tour. The tour was free and goes in small groups. It may happen that there are too many people and that the gate / access is closed at that time. So maybe you should also get a bit lucky or wait a bit (we waited fifteen minutes and were then able to go in).

Very beautiful both inside and out. Get ready for you to go out on the roof and it's super beautiful! Port and Lotus Tower visible. The tour is in English, but you can read the Russian translation of information from the phone. A lot of tourists and constant services, you have to wait for the prayer service to end.

In the busy Pettah markets on 2nd cross street, can view on two roads and take care getting photos as the roads are chaotic.  Just stunning and certainly worth a look.  We visited on a Sunday morning and the area was busy but not all the market was open, so I'd hate to see how busy it gets.  Very interesting place.

Built in 1909 and much extended in the 1970‚Äôs the Jami Ul Akbar mosque also known as the Red mosque stands on the street almost out of place for such an ornate.  It is hard to get a true impression of its size.  Magnificent.

The mosque is only beautiful on one side. Left and right of the slum. The way to the mosque is also through the slums with the corresponding continent of people. I wouldn't recommend walking around, especially in the evening.

Magnificent as it may be in form, what makes this the most amazing curiosity was its location; which, from pictures, gives the impression of an atmosphere bohemian and almost mysterious in spirit ‚Äì but in reality, was somewhat sandwiched unceremoniously between a row of plain non-descript buildings, lined with narrow, buzzy sidestreets teeming with locals going about their day completely unaffected by this immense grandeur rising above them all. This, to me, only made it all the more compelling. Don‚Äôt worry if you‚Äôre trying to track this discovery down, the Red Mosque is located right smack in the middle of Second Cross Street that‚Äôs in the hectic Pettah Market district, and is extremely easy to find even when you‚Äôre not looking. Don‚Äôt forget to traipse the madness of Pettah‚Äôs open air market while you‚Äôre there ‚Äì it‚Äôs possibly the best place to head to in Colombo to get initiated into the local Sri Lankan hustle and bustle.

Viewed only externally.. But what about it is really worth seeing .. A unique charm imposing and beautiful structure inspires respect. Beware of the road is very busy so if you take pictures watch out for cars

I visited early in the morning on an Uber motorcycle. I didn't go inside, but the pretty white and pink buildings that stood out in the city were impressive. I thought it was good to see it from the outside alone, but now I wanted to see it inside as well.
There is a fixed time when non-Muslims can visit the temple. Unfortunately, I went on Friday morning and on Friday I couldn't get in, especially after 4pm.

The mosque was built in the Indo-Saracen style in 1909, commissioned by the local Indian Muslim community, by architect Habibu Lebbe Saibu Lebbe. It can accommodate up to 10,000 worshippers after being rebuilt in 1975. It looks very dressed because of the alternating red and white stripes and is the oldest mosque in Colombo. Located on Second Cross Street in Petta amidst the bustling city shopping district where cars, tuk-tuks and hand-cart haulers endlessly swarm. The mosque cannot be photographed successfully because of the abundance of traffic. We tried to visit it towards noon, but a strict security guard at the entrance explained that now prayer time and entry is only possible after 4:30 or early morning. They went to look for other sights in the city.

Beautiful building outside .Interesting architectural style. Inside we never got ,said that will open at 16:30 ,and we arrived at 13h .Note ,the internet has information about the timetable of prayers .When praying, respectively , do not allow .Also for women separate entrance ,from the end of the building .
To enter you have to wear long sleeves and with covered legs, both men and women. It is a very nice place to visit and is spectacular the interior view of the entire mesquita.
Beautiful mosque to visit from outside and if possible pray there. Really beautiful. Must-see in Colombo during a visit.

While exploring the vibrant streets of Pettah, we visited the stunning mosque we‚Äôd heard so much about. The architecture is breathtaking, showcasing intricate designs and vibrant colors. The serene atmosphere inside is perfect for offering prayers and experiencing a moment of peace amidst the bustling market. Observing the locals perform Namaz was a humbling and enriching experience. This mosque is not just a place of worship but also a testament to the rich cultural and architectural heritage of Colombo. A must-visit for anyone interested in spirituality and beautiful architecture!
It is a mosque with a beautiful pattern. The complex shape seems to be a remnant of several expansions. Foreigners enter through Gate C, but you should avoid prayer time.

This imposing red and white building is in the centre of Colombo. We walked there twice, but unfortunatelly we couldn‚Äôt go inside because it was closed for tourists. It was prayer time because of ramadan. But I think it‚Äôs one of the most beautiful mosque I have ever seen.

On my first day in Colombo, I walked from my hotel to Pettah Market. This  was where I saw this unique and interesting mosque. Having traveled to several Islamic countries with various construction styles of mosques (Turkey, Indonesia, Morocco, Middle East countries, etc.) , I find this one very uniqie and colorful. Its exteriors are in the red and white colors , like in candy canes. Non-muslims can enter it, be sure your visit is  NOT on a Friday when non-muslims are not allowed to enter.
Very pretty mosque but the interior is nothing exceptional. We were unable to go to the terrace at the top of the building. The exterior facades are visible from the street and are magnificent.
It is jaw dropping to see this amazingly designed and coloured mosque rise out of the street. It is beautiful to look at. Didn't go inside sadly

When you first see the mosque from South Street it looks like a tower of red and white Lego blocks.  Inside it‚Äôs like a maze that Esher drew.  Inside is even more dramatic, made up of impressive angles, arches and countless wooden shuttered windows.  To enter, you go in a side entrance, remove your shoes and socks, if a woman borrow one of the hooded garments they have and wait for a guide.  A small donation is expected at the end.  (Friday is a religious day so I believe that there are no tours).  Your guide will show you the allowed route and you will be able to take photos when he says.  Once you‚Äôve climbed a a myriad of stairs, you reach the roof.  The city of Colombo sprawls out beneath you.  There are red meringue shaped towers protruding majestically into sky.  The red perimeter wall is punctuated with tiny turrets, with a sickle balanced on top.  The day I visited it had been raining and so this image was reflected delicately on to the floor.  The sun was setting, giving the whole mosque a mysterious quality.  A must see!

The Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque is a stunning architectural marvel, offering an awe-inspiring glimpse into spiritual and cultural richness. The intricate design and vibrant colors of the mosque make it a must-visit. However, the experience was slightly marred by unclear information regarding opening hours, causing some confusion during the visit. A clearer schedule would enhance the visitor experience significantly.

Terrific looking Mosque in the heart of down town Colombo however despite several attepts to enter, every time the place was closed to non worshippers but each time we were told to return at a particular time when entry would be permitted. Each time we followed the advice only to be disapointed and told again to return at another time. Without seeing the inside it's difficult to give feedback thus my average rating however from the outside it is certainly imposing and interesting looking building.
In the middle of the Pettah market, we can see this mosque, even if it is only from the outside, it overlooks two streets full of shops and people everywhere.

This is also known as the Red Mosque as is red!. It is one of the oldest mosques in Colombo and a popular tourist site in Pettah Colombo. It was built from 1908-1909. It is a distinctive red and white candy-striped two-storey building, with a clock tower, and is similar to the Jamek Mosque in Kuala Lumpur Malaysia, constructed in 1910. It was extended in 1975 to increase its capacity to 10,000

Also known as the Red Mosque, this is a must-see amidst the busiest part of Colombo. Visitors should head to Gate 3 for entry. Avoid Friday mornings as it is closed for visitors. A pleasant and friendly guide, Mohammed, who is part of the mosque administration team, shared about the history and architecture of the mosque, and guided us on a tour of the mosque, and answered all questions with patience. Proper covering is provided for all visitors to enable them to move inside the mosque without any disrespect to anyone. There‚Äôs a rack for keeping of footwear inside premises, which were very clean.
Make sure you have flexibility around cleaning and prayer times, we missed going inside,  but it looked fabulous from the outside
Jami-Ul-Alfar Mosque , Sammankodu Pallivasal, Red Masjid:  one of oldest mosque in Colombo. It‚Äôs good location . Local shopping area. Full crowded
Very beautiful! Bit of an experience getting there through the bustling streets of Colombo but worth a visit

We were passing the Mosque and got invited in for a tour. The young guide was very informative - if a bit over familiar. However it was an unexpected and culturally educational experience. Just be cautious.
Beautiful mosque especially in the evening. I‚Äôd definitely recommend an evening visit the mosque lights up and you really see the vibrant colors.
Pleasant but situated on a busy road surrounded by people and cara. Only one point of the mosque is viewable from the road and standing still seems like you are getting in peoples way

Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque is in the centre of the port area of old Columbo and it is a very unique building with an impressive architecture. It is located in the middle of a busy market area and it is not possible to do not admire this great building.
We went here as part of our independent city walking tour. easy to find. Great architecture. Make sure you kook at the building from the main street and also down the side  road to see the most.

Lovely architecture and very grand - you don‚Äôt realise how tall it actually is. It‚Äôs in a very busy part of Colombo so brace yourself. The women‚Äôs section is at the top and I found it a little hard to navigate around.

This is an impressive building, built in 1908, with the architecture that combines Gothic and Neo-classical styles, located within walking distance (10-15 mins) from Fort Colombo Railway Station. The Mosques was closed for visitors for 2 weeks due to CONVID-19 outbreak during our visit, but open for Muslims for prayer. It was already very stunning looking at the exterior of the  mosque and very instagramable building. Must visit for travellers in Colombo.

This Mosgue in the centre of the port area of old Columbo is a very unique building. It is a one off and well worth seeing, it sit"s in the middle of a very busy shopping and market area, but its outside facade simply stands out.

Very beautiful architecture, located on a busy road. Little bit challenging to take a proper photo, would recommend going early in the morning . The big disappointment  is that as a woman , you are not allowed to go inside to visit.

I've read countless reviews about how women can't get in and I really don't understand - that said, Google Maps took us to the tourist entrance, not the main entrance. From the tourist entrance, women are allowed inside and if not dressed respectfully, are given coverings to wear. Women aren't allowed past the courtyard, but it is still an impressive structure. We didn't spend much time here, but we're glad we went.
A must see place if you are looking for historical sights in Sri Lanka. i suggest you walk or take a Tuk Tuk to get their as the street is always crowded.

Known as the Red Mosque, its proper name is the Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque. Enclosed by other buildings on its two sides, it soars upwards. Its red and white stripes catch your eye. Completed in 1909, its architecture is a true hodgepodge of Indo-Islamic, Indian, Gothic Revival and neoclassical themes. It is located on Second Cross Street in the famed Pettah district. It can be visited by tourists. Its height makes it visible from many districts of the city, including the Fort.

Really beautiful structure, with the best photo being taken at the end of the road. Although it says it allows women, after we spent 15 minutes getting dressed up, we were only allowed to view the courtyard which was disappointing.

Most of the people missed this one for not getting the parking space.  But,  stop somewhere and go and visit is worth.  They will play one video about the mosque.  one young person who exclusively guide the Foreign Tourist.  I feel like Shivajinagar area in Bangalore
That mosque is on crowded Pettah road and it has very interesting style i have ever seen. It was created by an muslim indian, im honorful to visit there.
Beautiful mosque in Muslim street. The colours are so vibrant with white and pink. It is simply gorgeous. Took a moment to stand across the road to take a picture.

this is situated at a very rushing road in pettah! a typical busy street with different types of people working and shopping and all that jazz. its one of the best sights i've had as a street photographer and im loving the colours and everything about it! im a non muslim since then i do not know to explain its value through the religious sight. but im sure its very devotional.

As an atheist, I have never entered a mosque. This was my first when the folks at the gate welcomed us in. Women were given a full body dress to wear and we took photos inside the courtyard. We didn't step beyond that.

Jami Ul Alfar/  Red Mosque is one of the most unique looking mosques in Asia and lies in the heart of Pettah Market. Hence on a busy day one can take tuk tuk till market and walk here as it is crowded. Be cautious of pick pockets. It was build in 1909.It is a hybrid style of architecture, that draws elements from native Indo-Islamic and Indian architecture, and combines it with the Gothic revival and Neo-classical styles. We only did a photostop

We were only allowed to view from the street frontage; such a shame as it was like no other mosque that we had seen or visited. Magnificent building in red and white colours, it certainly stands out and is a feature of the street. It dates to 1908 and opened for worship in 2009 to cater for the religious requirements of the local Indian Muslim community  The architecture is described as a hybrid of Indo-Islamic and Indian. Beautiful minarets, domes and a clock-tower adorn the roof-line and tower over the building. Bucket list gem to visit if we return to Colombo.

It's in a very crowded area. Has shops all around it and the monument is situated right in the middle of a busy market. The mosque itself is very beautiful. Specially from the outside it looks very majestic. Beware of the tuk tuk guides who will try to lure you into giving a city tour of Colombo. Also, while you are in the area, do not forget to explore the local bazaar a bit. You can find some good shops here selling candies, souvenirs and what not. There is a big candy shop in front of gate number 2 of the mosque and you can buy chocolates here. They have very good options.

Whilst in Colombo did a half day tour with my designated tuk tuk driver. this was one unique coloured and original mosque i have seen, beautiful architecture from the outside, unfortunately it was closed so couldnt go inside. take pics and go so no more than 5 mins max!

Visited this during my visit to Sri Lanka, the architect was amazing and it really calms us when we are inside. Thank you Kingfisher Tours Sri Lanka to arranging us our tours and guided us to see these places in Sri lanka we will really miss them if we are alone

Myself & my wife were in the area and walked past the mosque, stopped to take in the lovely architecture and were beckoned in by a local worshipper who pointed out a tourist entrance. The streets outside are crowded and it's not the easiest to stop and photograph, however once inside we were welcomed in & provided appropriate clothing to pop-on whilst visiting. There isn't loads to see once in and it was explained that (obviously) most areas are single-sex so If I wanted to have a bit more of a look around my wife would have to remain in the courtyard area. To be honest it's a place of worship so we had absolutely no issue with that at all. There were a few staff who were very helpful and happy to welcome us in. Also the worshippers were all ok with us being there, I didn't head in to the prayer rooms etc. for obvious reasons as there were prayers taking place at the time. Overall, very pleased to be welcomed in the Mosque, and was pleased that my Wife was able to come in to the courtyard area which is the male entrance of the building, it's so impressive to see and whilst busy the whole area was a pleasure to be in!

I was quite intrigued by this location. Probably the most unique and elaborate mosque I have ever seen. The tour inside was short as we can only see so much of it, but the architecture and design...wow.
This mosque is a true land mark of Colombo , anybody who wants to experience pettah , cannot have a complete experience without visiting this great price of architecture
It is good to see but not worth the travel if you are not in the area anyway. It is a unique building, but there is not much to see there.

In the heart of the Pettah is the Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque, very distinctive and different with its red and white stripe design. Colombo is a religious melting pot, with about one-third each Muslims and Buddists; Hindus and Christians make up the bulk of the remainder.
An iconic place of Colombo. located a the busiest venue of the Island. History of over 100's of years. Indian construction Scriptures used.
Jami Ul-Affar Mosque is very narrow structure. Its is located in very dent place in one of the main Streets of Colombo. Similar Mosque was built at Kendy second big town of Sri Lanka.

What is called the Red Mosque is actually more red and white candy striped with a variety of patterns on the flat walls and also on the columns. It is a show stopper site to see. But it is in the middle of the busiest market downtown area so my driver could only pull over for a short time while I quickly hopped out and stood gaping at this magnificent structure in sheer awe.

The mosque is over 100 years old and is interesting to look at from the outside, with it's red and white striped pattern.   The streets around the mosque are narrow, crowded, and filled with people.  There really isn't anywhere to park.  I would recommend having someone drop you off and circle the block while you explore.  Unless you have a real interest, it only takes a few minutes to snap a few pictures, although you should not only take photos from the front, but also from the side entrance.
We didn't go in, but at least make sure you drive by this incredible Mosque while in Colombo.  Architecture is just unbelievable.  And the colors!!!!!

A Wonderful place in an Urban Commercial City of Busy Peoples who gather to this place more than 10,000+ for special prayers on Friday. Got to see the experience of this holy place with its beautiful Architecture and calmness inside

This mosque is based in the old part of Colombo. It was closed when we visited it. The exterior which is shown in all the brochures is nice enough, but does not compare with some really great Mosques in other capital cities.

If you are wandering through the streets of Pettah, the Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque can hardly be missed with its unique red and white brickwork. It is said that the Red Mosque has been a landmark for sailors approaching the port of Colombo ever since it was built. The mosque‚Äôs architecture and its red-and-white pattern, whether swirling or spiraling or alternating, is quite mesmerizing.
The main mosque of Colombo city, located in Pettha market. Nice architecture. You may skip if short of time
This is the main mosque of the city and located in the center of pettha market. Nice architecture...

During our tour of the streets of Colombo, we saw some very interesting sites/sights, this one caught our, the elaborate/ornate candy striping on the facade (red and white brickwork) is hard to miss. Definitely worth a look when in the area.
Amidst the hustle and bustle of the shopping district is this mosque, with its rich colours, design and architecture.  Can view from outside.

The architectural design of this mosque is unique and every distinctive component of her look is meticulously beautiful even without seeing the whole part of the structure. Most mosques in the world are not constructed with the same architectural design template. Singapore boasts of her magnificent Indo-Saracenic Masjid Sultan Mosque in Kampong Glam endowed with a golden dome. The unique Chinese style Sultan Ismail Petra Silver Jubilee Mosque (Beijing Mosque) in Kelantan (Malaysia) uniquely  combined Islamic architectural design with Chinese architecture. The Sultan Abu Bakar Mosque across the Johor Causeway has her attractiveness in her Victorian architecture. The magnificent and stunningly beautiful Omar Ali Saiffuddien Mosque and Jame' Asr Hassanal Bolkiah Mosque in Brunei mesmerized me with her grand and stylish Islamic architecture. Most of these mosques are located in serene and peaceful setting. I was amazed to see this red mosque within the precinct of the most chaotic and rowdy Pettah market of Colombo. When I came from the airport and alighted from the bus 187, I was confronted with a bazaar that was rowdy, crowded and noisy. It took me sometime to manoeuvre my way through the busy streets and eventually located this mosque. Nonetheless, the candy red white coloured of her fa√ßade made her distinctly different from the surrounding and stands out from the rest of the buildings. You can also combine your visit to the mosque with visits to other nearby attractions. Beside the Pettah market, there is an old town hall, a Hindu temple, a church and a clock tower that were built during the colonial period. When I was in Kandy, I also visited the red mosque over there but I still found this one in Pettah market a more impressive one. . Colombo may boast of her colonial building built during the British Empire days but this unique mosque is a must visit if you are in Colombo.
Red Mosque is a historic mosque in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The mosque is one of the oldest mosques in Colombo. Just near by the Petta street market.

This unigue-looking red and white mosque in the Pettah sticks out, but not in a bad way.  The beautiful interior is free for anyone to visit, and modest overclothes are freely available.  Only the immediate interior is available to non-worshipers.
Well worth visiting and it‚Äôs within the Pettah market area.  Very busy but interesting area.  The mosque can be viewed from 2 streets.

Came across the Mosque as we were walking around the Pettah  market area. It‚Äôs stunning architecture stands out with the red and white bricks of this enormous place of worship. You are only allowed into the courtyard and obviously you have to cover up but they provide robes for you to wear. If you are in the area I would suggest visiting and like us ask lots of questions as we did. Really nice polite young man who spoke good English spent time with us explaining the Mosque.

Beautiful artwork that seems out of place in the surrounding busy bazaar. Inside the mosque it is a lot more simple - marble floors and carpeted areas within. There are multiple prayer rooms within given that its tall but not necessarily wide. Wudu facilities are clean - the Sri Lanka Muslims tend to take water from a communal pool / large wash basin. They take water out from it using a large cup - so be prepared for muslims pouring water over their feet from a pool whilst maintaining eye contact lol. Peaceful atmosphere within.

Just on a short walk from Pettah I came across this stunning building. I wasn't expecting to visit a mosque so I wasn't dressed for the part and although there were robes for visitors to wear I didn't feel it appropriate for me to enter. I just enjoyed the external views of the building. It is beautiful, most impressive and highly unusual. The latest Lonely Planet guide doesn't even mention it whereas Footprints Dream Trip guide to Sri Lanka says that there's little of architectural interest inside, so perhaps external red and white facarde is all you need to see.Check out other reviewers photos. Well worth walking past if you are in the area.
Beutiful old mosque. Well maintained. In the shopping area. Some good restaurants around for snacks.
We saw this as we were taking a bus tour through Colombo. It was quite amazing to come across as we were just driving around town! We did not stop.

We visited the Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque as part of a city tour.  We were all disappointed.  We arrived early and were invited in by one of the men who worked at the mosque.  Unfortunately we entered by the wrong tour--for worshipers and men only--so when the man in charge arrived he was very angry.  We finally left, after our tour guide tried--and failed-- to explain the mistake.  That said, the architecture is truly unique and beautiful, both from outside and the small part of the inside that we saw.
- unique architecture draws the attention & the cameras - tourists only allowed to take pictures in the court - lots of hagglers outside to try to flag down tourists

This mosque is so recognizable with the two tone red and white. That‚Äôs why it is also so different on the outside from the ordinairy mosques with their domes and minarets. Nice piece of architecture in the old neigborhood Pettah.
A old place and a religious place to . From the out side you can see the color and the crafts of the Muslim religious place.

Not so far from Pettah Railway station- took 6 minutes walking. I was catching up morning train, and need a place for fajr prayer. This mosque really helps, in order not to miss early morning train, Neat and tidy place too in heart of city.
I visited this beautiful mosque with my wife and some friends. The architecture and red color of this mosque is the best part of it. We also prayed there and the workers there was also so kind to us.

Ruzni, the caretaker, was disrespectful and/or picked fights with 3 separate people (both locals and tourists) in the 10 minutes we were there. If he is replaced with someone calmer I would recommend visiting.
It is a lovely architecture. But it is located in a crowded area and unable to take full photograph of this building.
Working in the Middle East we are used to mosques but this was a very differerent style showing Indian influences. You could only visit a small courtyard but even so it was very impressive.

this is a unique mosque in the middle of a very busy area... unless you intend to worship there, you cant enter unless you are within the tourist vising time... the entrance for tourists on the side.. women cant really go beyond the inner square but the information office gladly provides overview and information about the mosque tailored to your interest and available time...

I showed up on a Thursday at 1745, 15 minutes after the hours.during which visitors are allowed, I was told to come.back the next day. I came back the next day at 10, was told to return at 1500 because it was Friday which is the main prayer day. I returned at 1500, only to be told I should come back an hour later. At that point I got mad, asking for a single answer. Visitors are only allowed into a tiny courtyard, visible from the front entrance. The building looks amazing, I wish I'd been able to explore.

We did not think ahead and forgot that Friday afternoon is considered to be major prayer period for the Muslim community.  The fact that the streets surrounding the mosque were traffic-free, many shops were closed and few people were in sight should have been obvious clues.  Nonetheless, we made a quick photo stop and admired the unique structure from the outside.  There is a "Red and White Mosque" in Kandy that we walked past but the exterior was not as vibrant as this one in Colombo.
Really beautiful building, in the heart of City. Anyways, there is no more places to visit so do not plan to spend more time in that place.
This is a must see spot while in Colombo. A beautiful building with great architectural features. Great photo opportunity.

This is a well maintained and over a hundred year old mosque in a very busy part of Colombo. Unfortunately, visitors are not allowed to go beyond a certain point to enter the main prayer area, or go to the higher floors. Worth a short visit

Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque Colombo, srilanka. built in 1908 one of the many colorful land marks of Colombo, Sri lanka. Add color to beautiful and Colombo. You'll find this high rising red mosq. The read mosq is a sight to remember. If u walk in the mid-day its challenge to get tough ppl and cart men who shout at u from behind 'side side side'. It's hot. Its busy. I Need to tell u that the streets of Colombo Fort area, in week days all of them were jam packed with people, street wenders who sells each and everything u can imagine for unimaginable prices. (cheep I say but most of them were 1or 2nd copies üòâ) so bring some pocket money in change, u never know.Charge your cameras mobiles and don't forget to carry enough water with you
It was locked, when we where passing by, but exterior is really worth to pass by, especially that it is in the district of some other temples, so not a long way to see it.
It is a magnificent building full stop. They did not allow our female companions to enter the mosque and we therefore decided not to visit internally.
You cannot go in, just take a picture from outside and move on. Spend 10 min if you are there, but no need to go for this.
The mosque is situated in downtown which makes it very busy to get to. It is huge inside and from outside looks small. Once inside you appreciate the beauty.
This big mosque is situated in the middle of the old part Pettah. The architecture is very special. One is allowed inside.

Spotted this wonderful building as we drove on a side road had to get out and take a look. What we saw was on a fraction of the building, it is beautiful the outside is so ornate with the colour and mini towers. You can see the building from many angles. We were there on a Friday and the Mosque was busy with men coming for the mid day pray so we did not get to see the inside. Worth a visit even if you do not get to go inside as the outside is a lovely sight to see.

In the hustle and bustle of Pettah, Colombo‚Äôs core commercial district, is situated a most striking building, a spiritual haven called Jamiul Alfar Masjid. This mosque is remarkable because the architecture is Indo-Saracenic, incorporating pomegranate-shaped domes.

The mosque popularly known as Red Mosque is located at a walking distance from the Colombo Central Railway station in one of the busiest part of the city. The facade of the mosque is such that it is in line with the other buildings along the main road as well as on the side street, however, it still stands out because of its architecture and the way it is painted. Red and White scheme is used for painting the facade which makes it prominently visible. Similarly the architecture is also very attractive. Entry is not possible at all times for visitors. However, the structure is also quiet photogenic and beautiful from outside.

I went on a City tour Taking a Guide and Car from a Private tour company namely Kingfisher Tours Srilanka and this place was so amazing the agent in the mosque explained us so  much about the islamic mosque that 100000 people gathers at the same time for prayers and i was like "Woah" what a mosque is it? I would thank for my driver to showing me such places and helping us to have a wonderfull trip to Srilanka
The mosque is beautiful and the architecture is quite interesting. Peaceful and has 5 times praying arrangement.
An impressive building accessed from the side street. We were welcomed in and allowed to take photos, albeit from a restricted area.
I did not expect such kind of beautiful mosque in Colombo. I prayed there. This mosque has an attractive outlook.
Very beautiful mosque from out side know as well as red mosque. try to go there in the morning to see the beauty of this building

This mosque is popularly known as the "Red Mosque". It is situated in the most busiest shopping markets of Colombo, known as central street. It is most unusual and unlike any other mosques, as the frontal structure strikes you as a Church, rather than a mosque. The minarets are not visible from the front and can be seen only from the sides. It has a checkered design of white and red and the pillars are like candy bars, from which stems its name red mosque. It's hardly 10 minutes walking distance from the fort railway station. Another difference was the Clock Tower, which also was rare for a mosque. Was not able to see the interiors as the mosque was closed.
The mosque has a very distinctive red and white candy-striped and a clock tower. It is situated amongst the very busy retail area of Colombo. It iscertainly worth a photograph or two.

Was built in the very beginning of the 20th century and its design and the colour contrasts strikingly with the surrounding atmosphere. Women are not allowed to go inside the building, but may enter the courtyard. Would be worthwhile if you enjoy architecture.

This masjid is very beautiful and clean. It has separate entrance and prayer areas for male and female worshipers. All tourists are welcome through the main entrance. However on Sundays the shops are close and so is the masjid, only the men section is open. However, women travelers are still allowed to use the women section by going through the men entrance.
One if the biggest mosque in Lanka. Located in middle of city. This has beautiful architecture from outside but nothing much to offer from inside of you are a non Muslim.

Nice mosque to see from outside as by the time we were there it was closed. They have told us it is opened to visit to women too which is a plus. Easy to reach and on the way from main market and other attractions around.

It is a small mosque in the middle of a buzzy bazar... Definitely worth the visit but avoid fridays because it is too crowdy! A very unique architecture and design for such a small mosque ... Vibrant beautiful colours.
A old beautiful mosque in midst of busy colombo streets. you may skip if non-islamic going inside as it does not offer much from inside and women not allowed.
Pretty building, quiet unwelcoming if you are female as no one spoke to you at all even though you followed the rules of not going inside. My husband went it and was quite impressed.

column7: La Fortuna de San Carlos, Costa Rica
column11: It looked beautiful in the photos, but being there, next to the mosque was a very different experience which i don't recommend for anyone. We didn't go in as woman are not allowed in and the atmosphere outside the entrance was horrible!

Historic Masjid in colombo Sri Lanka. known as the Samman Kottu Palli, Located in 2nd cross street pettah. Before other landmarks were built, some claim that the Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque was recognized as the landmark of Colombo by sailors approaching the port.
Really beautiful in its own way and no mind of leaving the mosque after entering the street is so nasty but the mosque is really peacefull
Lovely eyecatching mosque designed and built by a stone mason. Amazingly, it still looks very good - well maintained (only saw it from the outside)

Came to visit this mosque in the heart of Colombo city. Was not disappointed. Definitely makes for some good photo opportunities. Step inside the mosque to look at it‚Äôs nice infrastructure inside as well.

Based on previous reviews, was unsure whether I would be able to get in or not. Pleased when I therefore could- you need to go to the entrance on 2nd Cross St, not the original main entrance around the corner. Inside, there was a wonderful guide who explained the history of the building with accompanying footage and photos. You cannot go in very far, just the courtyard, but still very impressive and beautiful.

Colombo muslims call this mosque "Sammankodu palli (mosque)" and other people normally call this Red Mosque, one of the beautiful unique architectures in the city. The management board of this mosque did a expansion and renovation recent years without damaging and preserving the old structure.
I enjoyed visiting this uniquely designed mosque in Colombo as well as the many Halal restaurants in the surrounding area.
It is a very impressive structure. The architecture and color of the mosque is very different to the mosques we know.
Did not go inside but is amazing to look at on the outside. Definitely worth walking passed it and having a look if your in the area.

Located in the Centre of Old- Colombo in between Jam-packed street, this stunning mosque stands in all its splendour. A closer look at the mosque, you will definitely be surprised by the awesome Architecture and it resembles somewhat the mosque shown in Aladdin Cartoon. This place can be accessed on foot as there is no parking in the busy streets of Old Colombo. Lots of Local Street snacks shops nearby so you can try those after a long walk to the Mosque. Decent clothes are required if you are entering the mosque.

Jami Ul-Afar Mosque is located in the centre of the old town so the best way to reach it is to walk to it. It is in a very busy area, so even walking can be a problem. I think I would never decide to drive a car in Sri Lanka! The mosque itself is really beautiful from the outside. I didn't realiye where is the entrance for women and where was for men, were tjose two entrances separated all one for both.

Jami Ul-Alfar Mosque is a beautiful mosque located in central Colombo. It is a stunning building, made of red and white bricks. A word of caution, if you are going there better walk there, as it is located in a very congested area, where driving could give you nightmares.

This stunning mosque, is located in the heart of Colombo. Finding parking nearby can be an issue, so it's better to park elsewhere & walk. The Red Mosque is open to both men & women. Visitors must dress modestly. Should one require any relevant information pertaining to the Red Mosque, help can be received from the Masjid Information Centre.
The Jami Ul-Afar Mosque is located in the centre of the old town and has unique and attractive 'candy-stripe' decoration. It's worth a quick photo when you are passing.

This mosque suddenly springs out in the middle of a crowded street. It's bright colours will immediately catch your attention. Beautiful place but the surrounding area is really crowded so it would be difficult to find a parking nearby

The mosque is situated in the middle of a busy street in Pettah market. To clear your doubts, women are allowed in the mosque as long as they are decently dressed. The mosque is an architectural masterpiece!
Superb mosque which is an iconic landmark of Colombo. It brings in the unique structure of a 19th century mosque with the insides being renovated with modern styles.
If you are in the area, on foot, it's worth seeing. Quite spectacular architecture which shines out from a lack-lustre background.

Twsity one-way systems meant it took our driver a while to get us close to the correct street! Worth the effort to see this uniquely designed and painted mosque dating from 1908. Astonishingly, even as a woman, albeit with a modest dress below the knees and short sleeves covering the upper part of my arms, I was allowed i to the entrance lobby of the mosque. I was only persuaded to accept the nods of various people coming in and out that it was acceptable, because one of the Mosque staff came out to the street and, in good English, welcomed me in to enjoy looking up at the extension of 5 storeys and the towers. I had NO head covering and no leggins or long trousers, yet I was allowed to wonder at this extraordinary building, even looking discreetly into the prayer Hall! This should be especially noted for the welcoming attitude, quite different from some other mosques I have only been able to enjoy lookng at from outside! However, had I known beforehand of the option to have a guided tour of the mosque, I would have worn clothing I knew to be completely appropriate for a woman, and allowed sufficient time(about an hour).

This mosque is stunning with its red and white stripes and towering architecture. It is a mosque in use and as such, visitors should be respectful and dress appropriately. The mosque is in the middle of a busy street in a very busy market so it is not easy to take photographs but it is certainly worth making the trip to see it! I felt welcomed while visiting though I chose to visit on my own without a guide, just being in the courtyard felt relaxing and peaceful.

You walk along crowded streets...passing Muslims, Hindus, Buddhists... and, there, nestled among trinket shops, sari stores, and loads of fresh fruit is this gem.  It is gorgeous, note that you can only enter at certain times.  And, cover your legs and your arms (in other words, come respectfully).
It is very impressive structure i must say. Nestled right in middle of pettah market, it is very easy to access. Very peaceful place like most mosques.
Very impressived with the red and white brickwork when we first saw it from Grand Oriental Hotel. Worth to visit !
I have never seen a such beautiful Mosque, not far from Petha market. If main entrance closed, you can enter by a second entrance on the left hand side.
Beautiful colored mosque, peaceful and calm. Well worth a visit if you are in the area. Sometimes known as the Red osque
This mosque is fabulous, but it is located in a narrow street and the area is not very clean and smells bad. But worth visiting.
Beautifully designed Mosque, a must do visit or even a drive by if you are in Colombo. Ask you tuktuk driver, and he will be pleased to show you.

Had seen this building the previous day and decided to visit today on foot. I have seen many mosques in my time but none like this. The mosque was designed by a French architect, (Habibu Labbe) and designed in a Indian influence ( to be honest it reminded me of some London train stations and some Indian palaces). The mosque is very grand and very ostentatious with its red and whit brick effect. Tourists can‚Äôt enter the inner courtyard bit not into the mosque proper. Trust me - it is worth making the effort to visit this grand mosque.

I could not believe it when people told me that this is a mosque. It resembles the red church in St. Pettersburg in Russia. The mosque is very unique and beautiful and definitely the perfect spot to snap some really beautiful pictures. the mosque is located in a very tight and overcrowded street and you need to walk a little bit in order to enter to the mosque compound.

Beautiful and very different mosque to what I'm used to. Me and my partner could not enter at the time, but from the outside it is very beautiful. Only downside is the overcrowded and tight location, as it is built in small tight street and between buildings.
Nice to visit in the heat of the day. Very cool and peaceful entrance hall. Good place to have a pause visiting this area.

+ great colors and architecture, friendly people, busy and lively area, beautiful place of worship - as a lady I was not allowed to walk further than the entrance hall, no parking around, very busy and hectic streets around it, narrow streets so that the complete mosque was not really seeable from outside

Its a worth visit! Designer was so brilliant with the design of the mosque. Its stunning from the far as you can see the red/white colour of the brick. Its calm and comfortable as we entered the mosque.
Lots of Shopping Options and places to eat. There is a Jaffna restaurant by the corner and the coconut milk hoppers are a must have.
One of the true gems of Colombo.  Brilliantly coloured by amazing brickwork, the architecture is the highlight. Not the biggest mosque, but one of the most unique that I have seen.

The mosque is worth visiting for its brilliant architecture, which makes it visible from a considerable distance. The buildings that surround it in Pettah are not particularly memorable. There is no parking permitted in front of the mosque which makes for easier photography from across the street - having only to judge the gaps between tuktuks.
As a keen architect enthusiast I came here to have a look at the mosque and was totally blown away by it. Incredible building.
This building stands out even though it was erected in the busiest street of Colombo and is tightly surrounded and abutted by many other modern and ugly buildings.
We went by on Sunday, but unluckily it was closed. Looked impressive building from outsife with many floors. Worth to visit.

We stopped past to look at the outside of this interesting building but it wasn‚Äôt open for us to enter. Outside however was a snake charmer and a guy with a huge python. We happily paid an exorbitant amount to have the python draped round our necks and watch the cobras gyrate their way out of their baskets. Fun.

It is unique and stands out in a place like second cross street. The interior is also very nice. Surrounding the mosque is a whole lot of shops where you can find clothes, snacks, toiletries etc. After visiting the site, we went and had a good cup of tea n snacks, just around the next street. The area is very tourist friendly although women are not allowed inside the red mosque.

I had the pleasure of visiting this architecturally unique mosque. The place was very clean and well organized and maintained. The staff and worshippers were very friendly. They have an information center if you are interested in the history and background of the place (free). Both Muslim/non-Muslim men/women were allowed inside, even during the prayer time. They offer a piece of cloth for covering if the visitors are wearing shorts or so (free). Really recommend visiting it.

The architecture and finishes on this mosque which can accommodate 16000 people stands out as an example of creativity. It is advisable to dress conservatively. Ladies are not allowed in the mosque but can go into the courtyard. We were taken through a slide show on details pertaining to the mosque and its history. This was very informative and interesting. The mosque has six floors and the finishes are hand painted and carved. Beautiful... The idea behind the design is a pomegranate with the red and white carvings.
If you are travelling across Fort / Pettah do go to see this beautiful monument. Absolutely stunning

A beautiful and amazing Mosque located it the shopping streets of Colombo. You will be amazed to find it while searching for a bargain  amongst the narrow shops. We didn't go inside since we weren't properly dressed but it's definitely worth watching it outside. Don't know the history about it though which is little sad that they didn't have it avaliable next to it.

This is extraordinary architechture from the outside. I have been in many mosques from Marakech to Mayasia but this is the only one where I just wasn't allowed to see the interior. My friend's husband  and my grandson were allowed in and could take pics. So we ladies went next door to Ramona's in Main Street at #223 and went crazy buying sari's. You have to go all the way back to the rear of the store as the front part has western style clothes, handbags, lingerie etc. But in the back is where the magic happens. The salesmen are too nice and very patient with us as we are stereotypical goofy American women ( one lawyer and one court reporter) but we had a ball trying on saris which the guys teach you how to wrap. Took lots of pics and bought a bunch of saris and Indian style dresses with lots of embroidery and bling with matching leggings and scarf. Too much fun!!! Buy a bunch of stuff and there is a very decent discount on the total. We were made to feel VERY welcome. I recommend the store highly.
The architecture of the Red Mosque is absolutely unique in a mostly Buddhist/modern city.  Well worth visiting.
Its a pleasant surprise to see a mosque in this color, but when you hear the story behind this place, you will be able to appreciate the history behind building this unique and nice structure.

Jami-Ul-Alfar Mosque also known as Red Mosque is one of the century old and a historic mosque in Colombo. It is located at Pettah, one of the oldest parts of the city of Colombo, which is a busiest market place in the city. The mosque‚Äôs noticeable red-and-white pattern, which is quite mesmerizing. The domes are built in the shape of pomegranate unlike the traditional shape with the colorful brick patterns. The mosque is one of the popular tourist attractions in the city. It‚Äôs worth a visit to the area of the city to view its tall minarets, which are seen from the hustle and bustle of the busy nearby streets.

Beautiful Masjid in the bazaar area. Amazing architecture with very friendly and welcoming brothers inside. Although the women's section was closed they even found a little corner for my wife to make wudhu and pray Salah.

This sure is a great piece of Art. Built with such details that it is a pleasure to take lots of picture of it. Do walk around the block and you can appreciate how they have expanded by acquiring surround shoplots in a very unique way.
A very impressive mosque in the heart of the Pettah. A short walk from Fort Railway Station and the Dutch Museum.
Very nice and colorful Masjid in the heart of the local area. It was very large and with very nice architecture. From the inside, it was very clean a lot more than temples I visited.
We didnt go in as we wear wearing shorts , but its worth a look even from the outside..look from both sides too.

This Masjid is located inside a Bazar and is roughly a 10 minutes walk from the central bus station or from the fort railway station. You will pass through a couple of bazars before you can reach the entrance, I did not enter the Masjid so I am not sure if it is open to visitors of other religions but I definitely admired the look of it from the outside. A lot of shop owners were trying to sell something and I left earlier than I would imagine myself to because of them getting pushy. Unfortunately there is no one to check this issue. I reckon this place could pull much more tourist if it wasn't for the push sale issue.

Visited this mosque on a quite Sunday morning to admire the colorful architecture of the building. It would have nerve wrecking task to place those red and white tiles so meticulously. enjoyed the quietness of the place. During Friday prayer times the mosque is very crowed with the devotees.
This huge mosque stands tall in the middle of a crowded street close to a market in the old city. The architecture is beautiful and the colors beautiful.

The mosque is considered a very nice landmark in Colombo it is located in crowded streets. the staff was very welcoming they already have a room for showing you everything about the mosque and its history and how was it extended throughout a big period of time. must visit the red mosque if you love architecture and design.
We just admired from the outside (apparently women can't go in anyway). It is huge and stands out amongst the mish-mash of local shops surrounding the building. Lovely to see.

Amidst the hustle & bustle of a crowded bazaar in Colombo stands a predominantly tall gem of a building bathed in red & white, more red than white, Jami ul-Afar Masjid. Those who can also read Arabic script might get confused over Masjid's name as in Arabic it's written Al-Jami Al-Azfar. The original Masjid name might have got lost in the local translation, but not the grandeur and splendor it still holds. üå∫üå∫ Al-Azfar mosque was built in 1908 by the spices trading Arab businessmen who frequented Colombo port. It's considered one of the oldest Masjids in Colombo, and said to accommodate more than 10k devotees at one time. Indeed it's a colorful, unique, and marvelous architecture with an exterior of red & white brick pattern. The interior walls and ceiling are painted with white, golden, and green color, but the praying mats are patterned with exterior; red & white. Over the period of time the Masjid has grown, without changing its architectural pattern, into a 6+ floors monument. It's a huge building complex and one can easily get lost if one forgets the way one came in by. The absence of any direction signs doesn't help much to the lost soul either.üåπüåπüåπ As you entered the Pettah street from any direction you won't miss this Masjid, which appears as if a well decorated King standing among his ragtag subjects. Step outside the tranquility of Masjid and you will see street littered with shops, sidewalk stalls, and pushcarts selling merchandise including food, fruits, fabric, and female accoutrements. A paradise for those who indulge in bargaining, and a headache for those who prefer to go by fixed price tags.üåºüåº While women's access is restricted to outer courtyard, men (non-Muslims) are welcomed to visit every yard of Masjid, and provided wrap if they are wearing shorts. Have seen many tourists visiting the Masjid and was quite pleased to see caretakers of Masjid welcoming non-Muslims (male) into the Masjid and answering their questions patiently.üå∑üíê Good to see Sri Lankans (Buddhists, Christians, Muslims) gelling well together as a nation with harmony, tolerance and mutual respect for each others faith. I returned from Sri Lanka with more respect and admiration for the people of Sri Lanka and the friendly attitude they show towards all.üå∏üå∏ Thumbs Upüëçüëç

Among The trading people stand thuis architectonical amazing Mosque. You have to walk On main street and 2nd cross street to see this. You have to regard THE tuktuk's or people That transport goods with their hand made wheels. Not suitable with young kids or people That get parano√Øe of big crowds.
Still a vision! Crowded location. Lots of hustle. Just loved the colors on it. Maintaine quite well too.
Unique in both color and fascade. Located at a very busy street in Colombo. Must come and see personally to witness how majestic it looks
The artichecture and color of this building is definitely an eye opener for tourist. It is located close to the market within Old Town Colombo.
Were only able to visit from the outside, nice building, more than 100 years old, contrasting with the busy neighbourhood.

This glamorous towering edifice located in highly industrialized area of Colombo - pettah known as red mosque. Since it constructed in 1908 it is among the oldest mosques in Colombo. Its beauty reminds us a scene in Arabian Night with its architecture and nicely contrasting red and white brick patterns. It has been underwent progessive expansions and now it is said that it can accommodate around 10 000 devotees. You can visit this place between 10 in the morning to 12 noon. One more thing I have to remind you that you should dress appropriately. Women are not allowed in.

I took a taxi here understanding that this Red Mosque is a must see! And i was totally blown away when i saw the exterior and that beautiful infrastructure. As i walk over to the other side and to the main entrance, i was first greeted by some stares which didnt make me feel comfortable. I had some issues with the shoes as well, and was kind of told off by one of the staff there. I took a quick walk inside the place and found nothing special. The staff made me so uncomfortable that i didnt want to explore further and left. Total time spent, 3min! Therefore, my review may be slightly unjust,but i will just give this a 6/10 (I prefer to use my own scoring system as a scale of 1 to 5 is simply not detailed enough as compared to 10). It would have been lower if not for the extremely beautiful exterior. Its a must see ONLY if you are after infrastructures.

Spectacular historical site definitely worth a visit -- just beware that those suspected of not being Muslim will be shunted to a separate office. Best to enter with appropriate dress and explore with the locals to avoid being separated out - and money demanded of you!

This imposing red and white brick mosque is very strikingly beautiful. Very photogenic from all angles and exceptionally clean - like all of Sri Lanka. The soothing call of the priests is very melodious. A must-see destination if visiting Colombo.
this mosque near peetah market. built in 1908 with colourfull brick. we can enter this mosque. easy to find out
12000 can pray here at a time - that is quite a celestial e-mail! A testament to its builder a quick peek inside is worthwhile
What an amazing mosque. Such beautiful architecture. Built in 1908. Just wow. Each brick is individually paired red or white. This is a must see. There is not many places more beautiful than this
An unexpected site within a bustling area in Colombo. A highly recommended spectacle and a must see if you are visiting the city.

Red mosque is a place worth visiting. It is a very unique, colorful, architecture you will find in Colombo. This attraction is located in one of the most crowded place of Pettah (Pettah Market). You may consider visiting there together with shopping in Pettah market to avoid disappointment of being to crowded.

Beautiful architecture and definitely worth seeing. Don't worry if you're not Muslim you can still enter,  and you will be provided with a shawl if you are in shorts etc. However women have restricted access to the inner courtyard only, whereas men can wander a bit deeper into the building. (Bit boring for ladies).
Its a nice building located in the busy local market area. It is more interesting to walk around the market than to see the building.
Used to see different mosques and this one is particular, and very big, must be seen if u are around

This mosque is the hidden gem of Colombo. Situated in a back alley, one can forgive tourists for missing out. Once found, this mosque truly captivates the viewer. Beautiful architecture is on display, unrivalled by most mosques in the world. There is a separate entrance for men and women. The mosque custodian was kind enough to show us a tour of the mosque. A must visit in the city of Colombo no doubt.
The architecture is certainly interesting but the best was the conversation we had with the young muslim there. Make sure you take the time to hear the introductory 'talk.'

It has a great history, the legend says that it was built by the Business community who came to Colombo port for trading. Since the ancient times the mosque has grown to 6+ floors keeping the original architecture. A beautiful place to see. Recommend going on a Sunday or a holiday to avoid the traffic & crowded streets.

From its name , it is red and it is a mosque :-) However , the architecture is unique , it is not like the typical type of mosques that you will see in the Middle East or the Far East . It is multiple floors building with red color and it is still used for praying . The ( wodoo) area which is supposed to be in specially designed toilets is like a small well ( or swimming pool ) which is not common . The ladies also - even if Muslims - are not allowed to enter the praying areas but they can see the mosque from inside . No tickets , it is free of charge but you can leave donations if you like in a donation box .

This is well worth seeing from the outside (it wasn't open to the public on Sunday when we went.  It's bigger than it initially looks from the front as it covers almost one block.  Interesting street market in the vicinity too.
The colours and design of this place is eye catching. I certainly did not expect this design to be in Colombo - indeed different!

Visited for the Friday prayers and it felt like every Sri Lankan decided to pray at the same mosque! Looks amazing and very well kept but needs are few signs for easier navigation (easy to get lost!) Only bad point was that the website mentioned there was a women's section but there actually wasn't! Quite inconvenient for us as my wife had to wait around in shops nearby...

I was not allowed to enter the mosque for Friday prayers as they don't allow women to pray there on Fridays. I was really disappointed as I had looked forward to praying. In the end I just sat around in the shop next door (really good cheap bracelets available for souvenirs) waiting for my husband to finish his prayers. If you want to visit. Go any day other than friday!
The architecture of this mosque is beautiful and you can shop at the small shops that sells Sare . It's accessible with tuk tuk.
Came across this mosque while we got lost in Colombo. We didn't enter but it was beautiful. Warning: There are no toilets on sunday around this area so bring a bottle. Honestly!
Just a beautiful place to visit. We were given a little talk about the mosque. Very peaceful and interesting.

Worth the trip but only in combination with a nearby temple. It's a fascinating sight with the red and white colours and formidable size of the mosque jumping out against the bustling street shops and workers.
The worms welcomed made us shy toward our brothers in sirlanka thanks Hope to see you over in Muscat so at least we return some of the love we felts
An interesting landmark of Pettah, the mosque has a unique design and look, although today is sandwiched between ugly commercial buildings.
This miracle architecture design mosq built by ancient arab visitors, we though this colonial period
From outside it is very nice... From outside! Because I am a woman, I wasn't showed to get in. The area is nice at least.

This mosque is so pretty! And located in the heart of Colombo. Sometimes we tend to forget the historical value of Colombo as it's more urban than the rest of the country but the Red Mosque is a good reminder that Colombo has a lot to offer. Since we visited with a male friend, we actually went in with him (even though we were in jeans and tshirts, they were quite accommodating) and one of the maulanas explained the history of the mosque to us as well. Must visit place for anyone in Colombo for a short visit.
There were services happening when we went to see the building so we did not go in, but the outside of the building is really interesting and we really enjoyed seeing it from the outside.

Pettah market...lovely building among many in the crazy...market tourists not excluded at all ... the sights and bustle of the market and quiet interior superb lovely stone cbuilding fantastic peopleontrast
i vote it as must visit place in Colombo. beautiful & special also attractive architecture in busy street. better go here at 5-6pm, great sunlight that was cool

Beautiful building.  Mosque staff were very friendly.  Note that there is only a ladies prayer room at this mosque, and that there is very limited ladies access - a few metres inside the front entrance, essentially.

column7: San Sebastian de los Reyes, Spain
column11: The main point here is the area and the architecture of the mosque with its red and white stripes achieved with the bricks
interesting mosque in Colombo. The combination of white and red bricks is very nice. The interior is sober but nice.

As a moslem, visiting a mosque is mandatory. I am very surprised when some people ask to me "where do you come from?", I answered "Indonesia !!" then they talking with me using Bahasa (Indonesia Language). Apparently, the ancestors of the Sri Lankan Muslim population originating from the territory of Indonesia and Malaysia. With white-and-brown alternating patterns like "candy stripes" all over the exterior from the top to the bottom (six or seven stories), this mosque building is definitely a sight "appealing to the eyes" that is worth stopping by for a quick visit, and yes be sure to go through the front entrance from the street because that appealing exterior design is even more "stunning" when you look at it from the interior courtyard just inside the entrance. I also went inside the building itself and up a few levels, and was quite impressed by spacious areas with shiny marble floors & stairways although it was quite "bare" inside. By public transportation, the best way to get here is to take the bus to Colombo Fort which is Colombo's "main station" for both trains & buses (trains inside and buses outside; you can find here trains to popular tourists spots outside Colombo like those to Galle for going to the Galle Fort and those to Habarana for going to the Sigiriya Lion Rock, and also buses to various destinations both inside & outside Colombo including the Airport which is about two hours away from the city). From Colombo Fort, it's just about a ten-minute walk to the Mosque (first turn right to head east after crossing the road in front of the Station or just go straight ahead if you get off the bus on the other side of the road, then turn left into the street called '2nd Cross' after about five minutes, and the Mosque will be on your right just after about five more minutes along that crowded "market street" heading north). Afterward, you might also want to check out the Clock Tower just about a five-minute walk to the west from the Mosque (turn right into the first street, which is also another market street, and it will be pretty much right in front of you when you get to the roundabout at the end of the street); further west (about 15 to 20 minutes from the Clock Tower), there's a "charming" part of the city to walk around among nice well-maintained "colonial buildings" all the way to the Lighthouse.
